name: Beast2
tagline: Bayesian Evolutionary Analysis by Sampling Trees
body:
BEAST is a cross-platform program for Bayesian inference using MCMC of molecular sequences. It is entirely orientated towards rooted, time-measured phylogenies inferred using strict or relaxed molecular clock models. It can be used as a method of reconstructing phylogenies but is also a framework for testing evolutionary hypotheses without conditioning on a single tree topology. BEAST uses MCMC to average over tree space, so that each tree is weighted proportional to its posterior probability. We include a simple to use user-interface program for setting up standard analyses and a suit of programs for analysing the results.

## Book
A first draft manuscript of a book about is available [here](https://www.cs.auckland.ac.nz/~remco/BEASTBook/ComputationalEvolutionBook140115.pdf). The final version has substantial changes and is in proofs with Cambridge University Press, expected in April 2015.
We hope that this draft will be useful for BEAST users and developers in the mean time.
We invite any comments and remarks. Email us at: Alexei (alexei@cs.auckland.ac.nz) and Remco (remco@cs.auckland.ac.nz)

If you would like to cite it, please use:

Drummond, A.J. and Bouckaert, R.R. (2015) Bayesian evolutionary analysis with BEAST. Cambridge University Press.

## BEAST2 Wiki
The BEAST2 wiki is available [here](http://www.beast2.org/wiki/index.php/Main_Page)

## Authors and Contributors
There are many authors and contributors to the BEAST2 package. @rbouckaert is the main contributor to the BEAST2 code base. @alexeid and Andrew Rambaut were the founding developers of BEAST1.
